text: Hi everybody, we run lightsheet imaging on cleared samples. Any tips about oil (or any other imaging medium) RI 1.4 to use? We used to buy the Cargille oil but the price became unacceptable (995$/L :grimacing: ). The imaging medium needs to be compatible with immersion objectives. In our microscopes (i.e mesoSPIM) the sample goes in a cuvette, therefore the imaging medium doesn’t go in contact with the sample. Any tip is well accepted! Have a great day!

elements.text: Hi everybody, we run lightsheet imaging on cleared samples. Any tips about oil (or any other imaging medium) RI 1.4 to use? We used to buy the Cargille oil but the price became unacceptable (995$/L
). The imaging medium needs to be compatible with immersion objectives. In our microscopes (i.e mesoSPIM) the sample goes in a cuvette, therefore the imaging medium
go in contact with the sample. Any tip is well accepted

text:
Hi Laura,

We have a <#C04U9JFUU1M|clearing> channel btw, but Slack isn't the easiest to use, so I don't blame you for not finding it :slightly_smiling_face:

I found Cargille really expensive too, until I found <https://mccroneuk.co.uk/product/type-ff-cat-16212/|this supplier in the UK> who sells 480 mL of type FF for 161 GBP, 322 GBP/L.

Not sure if that is helpful, I use it for CUBIC cleared samples.

Other people suggested mixing silicone and mineral oil at 1:1 ratio, which is probably the cheapest for the higher RI of ~1.48 for CUBIC

You can try 2,2-thiodiethanol, it mixes with water to make different refractive indices, you might need a refractometer to confirm the final RI you get (see attached graph)

You might find some great information in <https://www.adelaide.edu.au/microscopy/ua/media/812/zeiss-tissue-clearing-seminar_lightsheet-7_university-of-adelaide.pdf|this Zeiss presentation>.

Not sure who posted that resource, but I've just been reading it, really useful!

attachments.fallback: Mccrone UK |: Type FF and Type HF | Mccrone UK
attachments.text:
Type FF is virtually fluorescence free but not ISO-compliant. It has a viscosity of 170 cSt Cat # 16212

 

Catalogue reference number for Type FF is 16212 and for Type HF IS 16245

 

Please specify the type under special comments when placing the order, or email to us.
attachments.title: Type FF and Type HF | Mccrone UK

text: HI Rob, that was a bunch of really useful information! Thanks for sharing it. I will definitely try those alternative to Cargille oil. Next time I'll write on clearing channel:) have a great day
